> Thanks for the link.  It does sound like what I'm looking for...though
> I was hoping to find a PhD program to enter directly, though that may
> not be realistic.  It's nice that the program is compacted into a
> year, though I'd guess it's pretty intensive.

From what I saw, most US universities at least require you to do basically 
the same amount of work as a master's degree before actually fully 
launching on your PhD anyway - but someone who's actually done that should 
confirm. If you already have a master's, PhDs over here are generally 
expected to take 3 years of research, with a possible 6 or 12 months 
afterwards to write up. This programme has been intensive enough, but 
definitely not too bad.

> It sounds a bit like the program at the Univ. of Sussex, which I did
> run across in my search:
> 
> http://www.sussex.ac.uk/informatics/1-3-2-2-7-1-2.html
> 
> Have you (or anyone) heard anything about that program?

I don't know much about their natural computation program specifically, 
but some of my coursemates went to sussex as undergraduates and they say 
that there are some great researchers there, although i think our NC 
program is better.

> > Additionally, it only takes 1 year for a master's degree over here - which
> > is a good thing because it does tend to be rather expensive in the UK. The
> > course was designed to identify good researchers, with a strong push to
> > continue on with a PhD. However, there are far fewer funding options for
> > americans over here, which is why I'm most likely not going to be able to
> > continue on here after this year.
> 
> That's too bad.  That does sound like it might be a significant issue
> for me.  Do they not offer research assistantships, or work programs,
> or something similar?

Joe already mentioned the ORS, which is pretty much the only option for 
american students; however, some places might offer international teaching 
assistantships, although its a bit hit or miss. The ORS looks almost 
exclusively at your undergrad grades (which was bad for me :() and 
excellent references. Schools will each usually get a certain amount of 
ORSs (the ORS is from the UK government), so some places are more 
competitive for them than others. However, the ORS does not apply to MSc 
programs; those you pretty much just have to pay for. Other schools might 
have more options but I personally just bit the bullet. And I keep telling 
myself that it was worth it, over and over. It was worth it, right? :) 
Actually, with the dollar so weak against the pound I'm glad that I'm 
making money in pounds or else I'd be screwed :)

> So are you finishing up your degree program this summer?  Are you
> working on a thesis right now?

The way this particular program works is that there are 3 courses in the 
fall, 3 in the spring, and one "mini-project" each semester which takes up 
about half of the time. Then for the summer we choose one of the two 
mini-projects and extend into a publishable project. I just finished exams 
last week so I'm taking a bit of a break but I should be starting my 
summer project in earnest in the next week or two. The courses were for 
the most part excellent master's level courses and I certainly learned a 
great deal, about evolutionary computation especially. I'm a little 
disappointed with the projects that I chose to do - you're given pretty 
much free choice if you can find a supervisor who will agree to supervise 
it.

no problem!
